title: Public Records Request for School Related Arrests

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Public Records Request for School Related Arrests
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

1.	Any and all documents relating to or filed in connection with school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). Specifically, we request such documents produced to include, but not limited to, the following columns:

a. Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement
b. Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement
c. Charge (or charges)
d. Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement
e. Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
f. Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
g. Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
h. Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
i. Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
j. Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school.
k. Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and
l. Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable.
2.	If such a production of the documents in question 1 is not possible, please provide any reports, incident notes, status updates, or documents which were submitted to DESE as the result of a school based arrest or any such referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced), per the U.S. Department of Education’s Civil Rights Data Collection for that year. For each referral to law enforcement or arrest, please include the school, demographic, and incident information described in DESE’s School Safety and Discipline Report Data Handbook v. 20.0.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joseph Steinbach

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Joseph Steinbach 

Attachments: 

https://cdn.muckrock.com/outbound_composer_attachments/steinbachj25/147035/PRR_for_DESE_discrepancy.pdf 
Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fboston-public-schools-122%252Fpublic-records-request-for-school-related-arrests-174717%252F%253F&url_auth_token=AAAdKRcKgn2WqZJR9oDkBRhSrsU%3A1t2iF9%3A3a8QE5E1KRRL5oso8ecLr0JsIt4lj7Nu8Bhf-DfRbLo A response to a public records request must be provided within ten (10) business days of receiving a written request.  G. L. c. 66, § 10 (a); 950 CMR 32.06(2)(b).  The public records law permits a response time of up to twenty-five (25) business days from the business day a written request is received, so long as a detailed explanation is provided.  G. L. c. 66, § 10(b)(vi); 950 CMR 32.06(2)(i). Due to the nature of your request, additional time is needed.  As such, the City will need up to, but no more than, fifteen (15) additional business days to review and process your request. Yours truly, Bianca V. Crockett, Esq. Assistant Corporation Counsel City of Boston One City Hall Square Boston, MA 02201 Bianca.crockett@boston.gov

communications.subject: RE: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request #R004276-102024
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I wanted to follow up on the following Massachusetts Public Records Law request, copied below, and originally submitted on Oct. 20, 2024. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.  You had assigned it reference number #R004276-102024.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: City Public Records Request :: R004276-102024
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
03/12/2025 RE: PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST of October 20, 2024, Reference # R004276-102024 Dear Joseph Steinbach: The City of Boston (City) has received your request for public records.  This response applies only to records that exist and are in the custody of the City. See A Guide to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, p. 32, n.115.  It is expected that a custodian of records must use her superior knowledge of her records concerning responses to public records requests.  950 CMR 32.04(5).  Specifically, you stated: 
To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records: 

1. Any and all documents relating to or filed in connection with school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). Specifically, we request such documents produced to include, but not limited to, the following columns: 

a. Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement 
b. Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement 
c. Charge (or charges) 
d. Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement 
e. Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement 
f. Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement 
g. Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement 
h. Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement 
i. Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement 
j. Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school. 
k. Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and 
l. Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable. 
2. If such a production of the documents in question 1 is not possible, please provide any reports, incident notes, status updates, or documents which were submitted to DESE as the result of a school based arrest or any such referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced), per the U.S. Department of Education’s Civil Rights Data Collection for that year. For each referral to law enforcement or arrest, please include the school, demographic, and incident information described in DESE’s School Safety and Discipline Report Data Handbook v. 20.0. 

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage. 

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Joseph Steinbach 

Attachments: 

https://cdn.muckrock.com/outbound_composer_attachments/steinbachj25/147035/PRR_for_DESE_discrepancy.pdf 
Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fboston-public-schools-122%252Fpublic-records-request-for-school-related-arrests-174717%252F%253F&url_auth_token=AAAdKRcKgn2WqZJR9oDkBRhSrsU%3A1t2iF9%3A3a8QE5E1KRRL5oso8ecLr0JsIt4lj7Nu8Bhf-DfRbLo The records responsive to this request have been released to the Public Records Center.  Click the link below to log in to the Records Center. The record is redacted to omit identifying information, including student names, dates of birth, id numbers, medical conditions, parent names, personal phone numbers, juvenile court docket numbers and warrant numbers in accordance with exemption (c) of Massachusetts Public Records law. The public interest in disclosure of this information does not outweigh the public interest of the individual. G. L. c. 4, § 7 (26) (c). You may appeal this response to the Supervisor of Records in the Office of the Secretary of the Commonwealth. G. L. c. 66, § 10A (c); G. L. c.66, § 10(b)(ix); 950 CMR 32.08; 950 CMR 32.08(1)(h) (in petitioning the Supervisor, the requester shall provide a copy of such petition to the records access officer associated with such petition).  You may also appeal to the Superior Court.  950 CMR 32.06(3)(c). Yours truly, Bianca V. Crockett, Esq. Assistant Corporation Counsel City of Boston One City Hall Square Boston, MA 02201 Bianca.crockett@boston.gov

title: Child care provider data (Dc Office Of The State Superintendent Of Education)

communications.subject: DC Freedom of Information Act Request: Child care provider data (Dc Office Of The State Superintendent Of Education)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the DC Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Historical data on all licensed child care providers (active and closed) from as far back as data systems will allow to present. I also request data on license-exempt providers, if available. Specifically, I request the following information as it is available:

1)	Provider name or ID
2)	Street number
3)	Street name
4)	City
5)	Zip code
6)	Licensed capacity for each year (by child age group if available)
7)	Enrollment for each year (by child age group if available)
8)	Provider type (e.g., center-based provider, home-based provider, Head Start, school-based pre-K, etc.) for each year
9)	First license issue (open) date
10)	Most recent license issue date
11)	Most recent license expiration date or close date
12)	Ages served for each year
13)	Hours of operation for each year
14)	QRIS rating for each year (please explain who is required to participate and whether there are financial supports based on rating)
15)	Accepts Child Care and Development Fund subsidies for each year
16)	Accepts other types of subsidies for each year (please list types)
17)	Prices for each year (by child age group if available)
18)	Violation records

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 15 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Gabrielle Pepin

In all future correspondence regarding this request, please reference request number R007768-022125. You can monitor the progress of your request in the " My Records Center". The District of Columbia is required to respond to your FOIA request within fifteen (15) business days of its receipt.  See D.C. Official Code § 2-532(c)(2011).  However, under certain circumstances, D.C. Official Code § 2-532(d)(2011) authorizes the District to extend, by ten (10) additional days, the deadline by which it must respond to a FOIA request.  One of the circumstances provided by that statute is a case in which the District needs additional time to search for, collect and examine voluminous amounts of records and/or consult with an additional D.C. agency. 
For any questions regarding your request, please contact the FOIA office directly. Find the list of agency Open Government and FOIA contact information by visiting FOIA Contact Information. For ease of reference, we ask that you have your FOIA Reference Number available when you contact the FOIA office. 
Regards, 
District of Columbia

title: Body Camera Footage (7/30/2022)

communications.subject: Wisconsin Open Records Act Request: Body Camera Footage (7/30/2022)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Wisconsin Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All unedited body-worn camera / bodycam recordings related to the following law enforcement critical incident:


Incident Date: July 30, 2022
Location: Apple River, Wisconsin
Offender: Nicolae Miu
Victim: Isaac Schuman

I am requesting all relevant footage, including any interactions between the police and witnesses.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Ivan LEE

communications.subject: Request for records received
communications.communication:
Hello,

I received your request for "unedited videos" from the Nicolae Miu case. This is NOT something I could release to you legally as all videos WILL be edited and redacted. There were many juveniles in this case and juveniles are a protected class, as well as victims who are protected under Marsy's Law. Below is the letter that explains all redactions made to all videos relating to the Nicolae Miu case. The cost to receive this request is just shy of $20 and it is far too large to send electronically. Please let me know if you are still interested in receiving the case file that was sent out to all requesters; media and otherwise, and I will send a flash drive and invoice around March. Thank you,

Dear Records Requester:

I am in receipt of your request for records regarding St. Croix County Sheriff's Office case SO2022006400. The St. Croix County Sheriff's Office does have records that meet your request. The Spanish language interviews are included in these records.

Pursuant to Wis. Stats §§938.396(1)(c)2 law enforcement records involving a juvenile may be released to another party only with the written consent of the parent, guardian, or legal custodian of the juvenile, or the juvenile themselves, if the juvenile is 14 years or older. I did not receive a single written consent form with any of your requests for records; therefore, all videos, photos, and reports mentioning or showing juveniles under the age of eighteen have been redacted or removed from the case files prior to release. The only exception I have knowingly made is that I have kept the deceased victim, Isaac Schuman's name only intact throughout. In applying the balancing act, disclosure of this already publicly named victim outweighs the interest in non-disclosure of this information. Pursuant to Schilling v. Crime Victims Rights Bd., 2005 WI 17, ¶26, 278 Wis. 2d 216, 692 N.W.2d 623. The public policy interest in protecting the privacy of victims of crime-especially children affected by very sensitive crimes-weighs heavily in favor of nondisclosure.

Well-established public policy recognizes the privacy rights of a deceased person's surviving loved ones. Cf. National Archives and Records Admin. V. Favish, 540 U.S. 157, 168, 171-72 (2004). In preparing these records for release, the Wis. Stat. § 19.35(1)(a) balancing test was applied, and the public interest in treating loved ones of the deceased individual with respect for their privacy and dignity outweighed any public interest in disclosure of any graphic images in photographs and videos of Isaac Schuman; therefore any images of Isaac and his family have been removed or redacted prior to release.

In conducting the balancing test pertaining to the release of law enforcement records, the harm to the public interest caused by the release of identities of victims of crimes overrides the public interest in release. Based on Marsy's Law, there is a strong public policy favoring nondisclosure of some of the requested records for the protection of the victims detailed within the reports. The policy implications as set forth in Article I, Section 9m of the Wisconsin Constitution and Wis. Stat. § 950.01 is that all victims of crimes are treated with dignity, respect, courtesy, sensitivity, and privacy. § 950.04(1v)(dr) states victims of all crimes have the following rights: (dr) to not have his or her personal identifiers, as defined in s. 85.103 (1) used or disclosed by a public official, employee, or agency for a purpose that is unrelated to the official responsibilities of the official, employee, or agency. In addition, there is a strong public interest favoring nondisclosure which outweighs the public interest in disclosure based on the potential for further victimization of the innocent victims. Wis. Stat. § 165.87(3)(c)1 - 1. It shall be the public policy of this state to maintain the privacy of a record subject who is a victim of a sensitive or violent crime and access to data from a body camera used by a law enforcement officer that records such a record subject shall be provided only if the public interest in allowing access is so great as to outweigh that public policy. Our department has received no signed consent forms allowing release of these victims' private information. Records will not be released that contain personal information regarding several stabbing victims from this case.  In order to protect the privacy of the victims and respect their personal information, victim names and images have been redacted.

In performing the balancing test, I determined that the public interest in avoiding unnecessary intrusion into the personal lives of persons collaterally mentioned in a law enforcement report outweighs any legitimate public interest in information about the conduct of governmental affairs. Furthermore, I determined that the public interest in protecting the privacy of these individuals, and in facilitating cooperation with law enforcement in sensitive investigations, also outweigh any public interest in disclosure of this described information. Any notebooks, reports, computer screens, audio, or video that may contain this information may be pixelated, muted, beeped out, blacked out, blurred, redacted, or removed. Additionally, the following statutes were applied in reviewing and consideration of releasing these records:


 *   Dates of birth, phone numbers, driver's license number, passport numbers, social security numbers and addresses for which we have not received a waiver to release have been redacted to protect against identity theft or other unauthorized use following any subsequent disclosure. In performing the public records balancing test, pursuant to Wis Stat §19.35(1)(a), I concluded that the public policy in favor of protecting the confidentiality of individual's identifiable information and preventing its misuse upon any subsequent disclosure, as well as the public polices outlined in Wis Stat §§ 801.19, 801.20 and 801.21, outweighs any public interest in disclosure of the dates of birth, driver's license/state ID numbers, phone numbers, addresses or social security numbers of individual persons.



 *   "Pursuant to the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA) and Wis. Stat. § 146.82, the St. Croix County's Sheriff's Office is not disclosing records that contain protected health information (PHI)." Wis. Stat. § 165.87(3)(c)2 governs people with a reasonable expectation of privacy pictured in law enforcement body camera recordings so some people's images, especially within the hospital, have been protected. Pursuant to Wis. Stat §51.30 and 19.35, medical information has been redacted or omitted. Medical records may be omitted from release as outlined in Wis Stat §146.82.


 *   Pursuant to Wis. Stat. § 51.30(4)(a), records related to mental health welfare checks are confidential and cannot be released except to the subject of the record.



 *   Cellphone extraction records are being withheld. After conducting the balancing test, I have determined that there is a strong public interest against disclosure that outweighs the interest in disclosure in order to protect the privacy of individuals who may be included in the cellphone extraction records that are unrelated to the case/incident.



 *   Pursuant to 28 USC § 534, information obtained by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and Wisconsin Department of Justice that is entered into the Crime Information Bureau is not being disclosed. Specifically, 28 USC § 534(f)(1) indicates that information from national crime information databases consisting of identification records, criminal history records, protection orders, and wanted person records may be disseminated to civil or criminal courts for use in domestic violence or stalking cases. Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to permit access to such records for any other purpose. Therefore, any information obtained from the national crime information database is redacted and not being disclosed, pursuant to the requirements set forth in 28 USC § 534(f)(1).



 *   Pursuant to Wis. Stat §19.36(13), personal and business financial account information is considered personal and confidential and has been redacted. Any and all invoices and bank related reports have been removed from your request.



 *   Pursuant to Wis. Stat. §165.79, Crime Lab analysis of evidence obtained from law enforcement officers are not subject to disclosure.



 *   Personal cell telephone International Mobile Equipment Identity (IMEI) numbers, which are economically valuable individually identifiable information, were redacted pursuant to the Wis. Stat. § 19.35(1)(a) balancing test to protect against identity theft or other unauthorized use following any subsequent disclosure. In applying the balancing test, DOJ determined the public interest in protecting this economically valuable individually identifiable information from misappropriation or misuse outweighs any public interest in disclosure.

In conducting the balancing test pursuant to Wis. Stat. § 165.87(3)(c)2, the public's interest in disclosure of other jail inmates is not outweighed by the public interest in non-disclosure. Jail inmates who are not the subject of the record have an expectation of privacy in the jail.

Please be advised that any video which has been redacted to the point there is nothing of value left to release has been omitted from this release.

The Wisconsin Public Records laws exist to ensure an open and transparent government. The personal communication of an inmate does not affect government business operations unless it involves a potential safety or security issue as identified in DOC 309.39. Although the inmate is informed of the recordings  of the calls, he or she would likely to be reluctant to communicate if these records were disclosed as a public record. This impact on communication if treated as a releasable public record would undermine the rehabilitative aspect of maintaining communication between the inmate and the inmate's family, friends, government officials, courts and people concerned with the welfare of the inmate. Open communication fosters reintegration into the community and the maintenance of family ties. It motivates the inmate and contributes to the morale and security of the inmate and staff. For these reasons the St. Croix County Sheriff's Office has determined that any of Nicolae Miu's phone calls, video logs, visitation reports, or activities from within our jail are not being released with your request for records.


There may be more information about law enforcement records pursuant to this request, but the St. Croix County Sheriff's Office is not the legal custodian of those records.
Please feel free to contact me with any questions regarding the above information. If you believe the St. Croix County Sheriff's Office is withholding the requested records, you may request the St. Croix County District Attorney or the Wisconsin Attorney General to commence an action for mandamus for release of the records on your behalf. Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 19.37(1), you may also file an action for mandamus on your own behalf.

Sincerely,

communications.subject: RE: Wisconsin Open Records Act Request: Body Camera Footage (7/30/2022)
communications.communication:
Hello,


Would it be possible to send the requested materials via email if the file size can be reduced? Specifically, I am requesting only the police bodycam footage from the date of the incident (7/30/2022).

If the file size remains too large:
Please ensure that the bodycam footage containing the following reference numbers is included:

guest BC22006747
istumo BC22006743


For the remaining footage, I would greatly appreciate it if you could select and include as much as possible within the limits of what can be sent by email.
Thank you for your understanding and assistance. I look forward to your response.

communications.subject: RE: Wisconsin Open Records Act Request: Body Camera Footage (7/30/2022)
communications.communication:
Due to the amount of redactions and the size of the case, every one of the videos are entirely too large to send electronically. Believe me, we have tried. We have received more than 25 previous requests for this case file. I am afraid I do not understand the reference numbers you have provided. Where did these come from? We do not use those types of numbers or labeling to mark any of our videos. Please feel free to call me if you would like to explain further what it is you are looking for. Again, there were several juveniles and victims in the Nicolae Miu case, so the videos are very heavily redacted.

We are very limited to how much cloud storage we are allotted, and I am a one-woman records department who has handled more than 2,500 requests for records so far this year. We have determined that agency requests must take precedence for what we can send electronically as we work with several other law enforcement agencies in order to handle important cases. Any costs are based on our actual cost of producing the records requested so the cost is only for the cost of the flash drive and the postage.

Your request is in my queue; however, there are almost thirty requests received prior and request for videos are handled in the order in which they are received. I will keep your request in my queue unless I hear otherwise.

Thank you,


[cid:sheriffsiglogo2_1855255d-257b-4278-957c-61a991b79423.jpg]<https://sccwi.gov/>

Please feel free to contact me with any questions regarding the above information. If you believe the St. Croix County Sheriff's Office is withholding the requested records, you may request the St. Croix County District Attorney or the Wisconsin Attorney General to commence an action for mandamus for release of the records on your behalf. title: Number and impact of data center customers (Klickitat County Public Utility District)

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Number and impact of data center customers (Klickitat County Public Utility District)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Number of Data Center Customers - The total number of customers categorized as "data centers" or equivalent from January 1, 2019, to the present, broken down by year.
2. Electricity Consumption - The total electricity consumption (in kilowatt-hours or megawatt-hours) attributed to data center customers for each year from January 1, 2019, to the present.
3. Growth of Data Center Customers - Year-over-year growth (in terms of number and consumption) of data center customers from January 1, 2019, to the present.
4. Internal Communications - All internal communications, including emails, meeting minutes, memos, and reports, related to policies, plans, or discussions on serving data center customers, dated from January 1, 2019, to the present.
5. Policies and Guidelines - Any official or draft policies, guidelines, or procedures created, revised, or implemented since January 1, 2019, that address the operation, service rates, or requirements for data center customers.

To assist in processing this request, I am specifically interested in documents, communications, or data related to:
- Power usage and billing structures for data center customers.
- Discussions on accommodating the growth of data centers in the service area.
- Environmental and infrastructure impact considerations related to data center customers.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Robin Monks
We are in receipt of this request and are working through collecting the requested information.

Please see our response to your questions listed above and within the information request. 
#1. KPUD has 0 Data Center Customers
#2 KPUD has 0 electricity consumption associated with data centers. 
#3KPUD has 0 growth of data center customers
#4 KPUD has some internal communications associated with Data Center load requests. This information is under review.
#5 We have included Policy 43 and any edits approved since 2019. 
- Power usage= 0
-Discussions accommodating growth- Under evaluation
- Environmental impacts= 0 to date
I anticipate providing one more update before the completion of this request.

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request #Datacenters 2025
communications.communication:
Thank you for sending along the records to date.
I noted in the email search you sent (DateCenter.pst) the query used was "date center" or "date centers"; the query should be "data center" or "data centers" to match the parameters of the request. It looks like there was a typo when conducting the original query.

Appreciate your help and am looking forward to receiving the corrected search and remaining documentation.

Take care,
Robin
We have received your email search verification. Our IT department has been notified and I am awaiting a response. The remaining data is under legal review. I will have another update by February 14.

We found additional information with the "data center" email search correction. We are still reviewing potentially confidential or proprietary information. So we will provide a further update by February 21.

Attached are additional documents responsive to the requester's parameters.  We have a few more documents awaiting legal review. We will complete our submission by the March 5, 2025 date referenced above.

I am writing to provide an update on our progress regarding your FOIA request. The remaining documents are currently under legal review to ensure compliance with our non-disclosure agreements. We apologize for any inconvenience this may cause.

Our legal counsel has requested that we extend the completion date to March 12. At this time, we do not anticipate any additional delays, but we will reach out if anything changes. Unfortunately, I am unable to provide any documents at this time, as all remaining materials are still under legal review.

Thank you for your understanding. If you have any questions or need further information, please feel free to contact me at lmata@klickpud.com.
Respectfully, 
Luann Mata

title: California Public Records Request: mobile device forensic tools

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: California Public Records Request: mobile device forensic tools
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records regarding the thousand oaks police Department’s use of mobile device forensic tools (MDFTs). 
This includes any software, hardware, process, or service that is capable of any of the following:
• extracting any data from a mobile device,
• recovering deleted files from a mobile device, or
• bypassing mobile device passwords, locks, or other security features.
Examples of MDFTs include, but are not limited to, products or services offered by vendors such 
as Cellebrite, Grayshift, Oxygen Forensics, BlackBag Technologies, Magnet Forensics, MSAB, 
AccessData, Paraben, Katana Forensics, BK Forensics, and Guidance Software/OpenText. 
I specifically requests the following records under the California public records act 
1. Purchase Records and Agreements: Any and all records reflecting an agreement for purchase, 
acquisition, or license of MDFTs, or permission to use, test, or evaluate MDFTs since 2015. 
2. Records of Use: Any and all records describing the Department’s use of MDFTs since 2015.
a. In particular, we seek records reflecting the department’s aggregate use of MDFTs. For 
example, monthly reports that reflect the total number of MDFT cases for each month, 
broken down by type of crime, and number and type of phones, and number and type of 
other devices.
i. Please specify any instances where the department used Cellebrite Advanced Services, 
or otherwise transferred possession of a device or its contents to a vendor for off-site 
processing, including Regional Computer Forensics Laboratories.
ii. Please include any instances of forensic examination of a device (e.g. using JTAG or 
chip-off processes) that may not involve a vendor’s product. 
3. Policies Governing Use: Any and all records regarding policies and guidelines governing the 
use of MDFTs, including but not limited to: training materials regarding their operation, 
restrictions on when they may be used, limitations on retention and use of collected data, 
security measures taken to protect stored and in-transit data, guidance on when a warrant or 
other legal process must be obtained, and guidance on when the existence and use of MDFTs 
may be revealed to the public, criminal defendants, or judges.
Due to the ubiquity of mobile devices, law enforcement sees the data stored on mobile devices, 
like cellphones, as key sources of evidence for investigations. However, mobile devices can 
contain large amounts of people’s sensitive and private information, much of which may be 
irrelevant to a given investigation. As the Supreme Court recognized in Riley v. 
California, “[o]ne of the most notable distinguishing features of modern cellphones is their 
immense storage capacity.” As such, forensic searches of mobile devices are often highly invasive, 
and we believe that such searches by law enforcement are increasingly common. 
Mobile device forensic tools (MDFTs) are used by law enforcement to extract data from mobile 
devices. In some cases, if the data on the mobile device is encrypted, some MDFTs can help law 
enforcement circumvent a device’s security features in order to access otherwise inaccessible 
data. These capabilities have been the subject of broad public debate, for example, in the 
aftermath of the high-profile San Bernardino shooting in 2015. Whether or not devices are 
encrypted, law enforcement’s use of MDFTs is an issue of significant public interest. 
Currently, there is a considerable lack of public information available regarding how local 
law enforcement agencies use MDFTs, and the policies and procedures that govern such 
use. The public is entitled to understand the Department’s activities and capabilities with 
respect to MDFTs, and this request seeks to further the public’s understanding.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Mr. adonis gaynor

title: 2010 Crime Incidents Request (Baton Rouge Police Department)

communications.subject: Louisiana Public Records Law Request: 2010 Crime Incidents Request (Baton Rouge Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Louisiana Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting data on crime incidents—those classified by your agency as crimes—rather than calls for service or unfounded incidents.
• Year(s) Requested: 2010
• Columns Requested: Incident date, Incident time, Type of crime (e.g., robbery, theft, etc.), Incident ID, and all other available columns that do not require additional processing by the agency or redaction.

If the data are stored in a proprietary or custom electronic format not publicly available, I request that it be converted to a format viewable with standard software, such as Microsoft Excel or CSV. Please avoid providing data in PDF or paper printouts.

This request is made to support academic research conducted in the public interest and is not for commercial purposes. The data will contribute to a research project assessing the effect of music concerts on crime, aiming to enhance public understanding of how large events influence community safety.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kristina Block

communications.communication:

communications.subject: Police Request :: P006462-030525
communications.communication:
Dear Kristina Block: 
Thank you for visiting the City of Baton Rouge Public Records Center.  We are in receipt of your request for records.  We will process your request; once your records are available, we will alert your office. Due to high volume of requests received by our office, please allow at least thirty days for production of any records that may be available.  Your request was received in this office on 3/5/2025 and assigned the reference number P006462-030525 for tracking purposes. 
 
 Records Requested: To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Louisiana Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting data on crime incidents—those classified by your agency as crimes—rather than calls for service or unfounded incidents.
• Year(s) Requested: 2010
• Columns Requested: Incident date, Incident time, Type of crime (e.g., robbery, theft, etc.), Incident ID, and all other available columns that do not require additional processing by the agency or redaction.

If the data are stored in a proprietary or custom electronic format not publicly available, I request that it be converted to a format viewable with standard software, such as Microsoft Excel or CSV. Please avoid providing data in PDF or paper printouts.

This request is made to support academic research conducted in the public interest and is not for commercial purposes. The data will contribute to a research project assessing the effect of music concerts on crime, aiming to enhance public understanding of how large events influence community safety.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kristina Block

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fbaton-rouge-police-department-5230%252F2010-crime-incidents-request-baton-rouge-police-department-182450%252F%253Femail%253Dbrla%252540govqa.us&url_auth_token=AAAbwP3wXyfDUJSF6YykvNBj8wI%3A1tq1QH%3AYhS5wUCLJa52qaXCcLwoajCzNWklb5ckvLF7_dtUdrg 
To the extent the records pertain to an ongoing criminal or administrative investigation/prosecution, the relevant records will not be subject to disclosure pursuant to LSA-R.S. 44:3, unless otherwise deemed releasable pursuant to the BRPD Public Release of Critical Incident Recording Policy. 
Monitoring the progress of your request is available by using the link below.  Again, thank you for using the City of Baton Rouge Public Records Center. 
 
PLEASE NOTE:  Louisiana Public Records Law does not require a governmental body to create a new document in response to a request for public records.

title: City Storage Program Policy documentation

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: City Storage Program Policy documentation
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Any documents pertaining to the "City Storage Program Policy" as described by "An Ordinance to amend Ch. 24 by adding a new section relative to Camping" section 24-31(g)(i): "The Salem Police Chief shall establish, and from time to time amend, a City Storage Program Policy not inconsistent with this ordinance." Including current and prior versions of the written copy of the "City Storage Program Policy" as pursuant to 24-31(g)(v), any amendments to the current written copy of the "City Storage Program Policy", and any notes kept regarding the current written copy of the "City Storage Program Policy" from the Salem Police Department since the establishment of "An Ordinance to amend Ch. 24 by adding a new section relative to Camping" to the date this request was sent, January 13, 2025.

As well as,

All documents from the June 26, 2024 dispersal of the 'South River encampment' pertaining to "reasonable and documented attempts" made by "City staff" to identify owners of "property" that was left at the South River encampment as a result of this June 26 dispersal that was "not claimed by any person within 24 hours of it being deemed by the City as being unclaimed" in which case "City staff" are to "assess whether the property is abandoned property or an individual’s temporarily unattended property through reasonable and documented attempts to identify the property owner" as is required of the "City Storage Program Policy" pursuant to 24-31(g)(iii).

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. I am currently a student journalist at Emerson College and have reported about the South River encampment in the past. As these records pertain to the transparency of our public officials in the treatment of homeless community members on public grounds, I would request the fees for this request be waived on the grounds of clear public interest as is suggested by the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. As section 24-31(g)(vii) lays out how fees should not be charged in regards to processing claims in filing appeals to recover property pursuant to the "City Storage Program Policy," I would ask that this standard be extended to this request as it is not made in the commercial interest but in the interest of transparency regarding the same policy. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and will not be made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Adam Nuñez

communications.subject: Re: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: City Storage Program Policy documentation
communications.communication:
We have received your request for possible records and a response will be provided within 10 business days per Mass Public Records Law<https://www.sec.state.ma.us/pre/prepdf/guide.pdf> to your respective request; distribution of information being requested may take longer indicative of the nature and or volume of information being sought. Thank you for your patience.

**Note - Depending on the volume of records which you are requesting (and or needs to be searched to fulfill this request), we will communicate prior to completing your request a 'cost estimate' (and timeframe) in accordance with Mass Public Records Law<https://www.sec.state.ma.us/pre/prepdf/guide.pdf> for the completion/distribution of the information which you are requesting.

In the event we are not the 'Keeper of the Record' for the information you are seeking or 'No records Found' we will do our best to instruct you to the correct agency for the information being requested.

If this office can be of further assistance in the interim, please let us know.

Respectfully,

To Whom It May Concern:

Thank you for fulfilling the first portion of my response. Was there any corresponding records regarding the second portion? (copy and pasted below)

"All documents from the June 26, 2024 dispersal of the 'South River encampment' pertaining to "reasonable and documented attempts" made by "City staff" to identify owners of "property" that was left at the South River encampment as a result of this June 26 dispersal that was "not claimed by any person within 24 hours of it being deemed by the City as being unclaimed" in which case "City staff" are to "assess whether the property is abandoned property or an individual’s temporarily unattended property through reasonable and documented attempts to identify the property owner" as is required of the "City Storage Program Policy" pursuant to 24-31(g)(iii)."

Thank you for your time.

From,

communications.subject: Re: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: City Storage Program Policy documentation
communications.communication:
Muckrock,

Please see the attached clarification request that we received from your agency (document attached for reference).

Below is the response from Capt. Burke who oversees the CIU (Community Impact Unit):

All individuals were aware that the site was being closed and had ample time to remove any property that they wished.  Anyone who wanted to have the PD store property would have been able to do so.  Not one individual requested we store their personal property.  This was not unexpected as most individuals, housed or unhoused, do not want to turn over their possessions to the police.  However, we were on site to do so on the date of the closure.  Again, no one wanted to give officers property.

The remaining items (tents, furniture, misc. Items, etc.) were so highly contaminated by human waste and hypodermic needles that it would not be permissible to store at the station safely.

Officers also asked individuals if they had everything they wanted to retrieve.

No one has come forward to tell us that any property that was wanted was disposed of.

Also lastly, there is mention of the property in the report.  That would be our documentation.  There would be no separate report.


If this office can be of any other assistance, please let us know.



Respectfully,



If you wish to challenge any aspect of this response, you may appeal to the Supervisor of Public Records following the procedure set forth in 950 C.M.R. 32.08, a copy of which is available at

http://www.mass.gov/courts/case-legal-res/law-lib/laws-by-source/cmr/<https://linkprotect.cudasvc.com/url?a=https%3a%2f%2flinklock.titanhq.com%2fanalyse%3furl%3dhttp%253A%252F%252Fwww.mass.gov%252Fcourts%252Fcase-legal-res%252Flaw-lib%252Flaws-by-source%252Fcmr%252F%26data%3deJxljM0KgzAQhJ_G3BJsI0oPOXhpS699gjWuUcmPZGODb99Ij4VhmBk-Rqu26bpBtvJWTxdko9IxZL94mhe0o9DBMaee2KyvvnsfDxMZKTAR0WPV1AQW3TYKj4lFtU7goKz_F7uaU9oq2VfXe1HOWTggEiZ8StVhj4nOAITcogHLI56DhcztMvwS8eHgVFiNJ-ti8S9s8kFM&c=E,1,9wSSFxRFBoCPkfGE9giAhbeiiMiNeJa2thFtN3KO3mXdBru7FvRDbyhMmQdWKzs3wlXwPj0Dh1DNotHM_IJRgAK8YD9z6um0cWRVDQpA&typo=1>

title: SB34 ALPR Data Sharing (Oakland Police Department)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: SB34 ALPR Data Sharing (Oakland Police Department)
communications.communication:
Dear Custodian of Records:

This letter constitutes a request under the California Public Records Act ("CPRA") from the Electronic Frontier Foundation, submitted with the assistance of MuckRock News. 
We request the following records related to Automated License Plate Readers ("ALPRs") and your law enforcement agency ("Agency").

Part A - Information related to ALPR data sharing.
A1. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares ALPR data;
A2. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives ALPR data;
A3. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares “hot list” information;
A4. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives “hot list” information.

The information requested in items A1-A4 is readily available for extraction through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Data Sharing Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality.  

Most agencies have encountered little difficulty in providing this information (see below). In a small number of cases, an agency has interpreted items A1-A4 as requesting the creation of a record that does not exist. We disagree: this data is maintained by your software, can be exported through software your agency has already purchased, and is therefore subject to CPRA. 

However, should you disagree, you may alternatively produce the following records:  

A5. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents that external agencies have signed to comply with Sec 1798.90.52(b) for accessing your agency's ALPR data. These documents are also often required under the "Releasing ALPR Data" subsection of a California law enforcement agency's SB 34 policy. 

A6. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents  that your agency has signed pursuant to Sec 1798.90.52(b) to access other agencies' ALPR data.

A7. All "records of access" required by Sec. 1798.90.52(a) for the periods January 1, 2021 until the date of processing this request. 

Items A5-A7 are not necessary if your agency provides the information requested in items A1-A4. We feel that items A1-A4 are more focused and would require less labor from your agency to produce. 

Part B - Information Related to Numbers of “Detections” (plate scans) and “Hits” (plate scans that matched to a hotlist)
B1. The aggregate number of "detections" collected during 2023.

B2.  The aggregate number of “hits” during 2023.

B3. The aggregate number of "detections" from January 1, 2024 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period. For example, most Flock Safety systems may not have this data beyond 30 days. 

B4.  The aggregate number of “hits” from January 1, 2024 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period.

The information requested in items B1-B4 is readily available through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Hit Ratio Report function. With Flock Safety, this information  is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality.  As noted above, this information exists within your system and can be easily exported with existing software.

Please note that more than 80 California law enforcement agencies have provided the information requested in Parts A1-A4 and B1-B4 in previous years. For your reference we have included a table (attached) with the names of the agencies that have historically provided these records. 

CPRA requires you to undertake reasonable efforts to locate responsive records and to work in good faith with requesters to respond to their request. See CYAC v. City of National City, 220 Cal.App.4th 1385, 1430 (2013). Thus under the CPRA you are obligated to conduct a reasonable search and cannot deny a request merely because it might generate a large volume of records. 

We ask that you please respond to this request within 10 days either by providing all the requested records or by providing a written response setting forth the legal authority on which you rely in withholding or redacting any document, as well as stating when documents will be made available. Should you choose to withhold or reject this request, we ask that you provide an explanation of why your agency is responding differently compared to the many others that have complied with our request. 
 
We also request that any records maintained in an electronic format be provided in that same format (such as a PDF, CSV or XLS file), to avoid copying costs.

However, should you be unable to do so, EFF will reimburse you for the direct costs of copying these records (if you elect to charge for copying) plus postage. If you anticipate that these costs will exceed $25.00, or that the time needed to copy the records will delay their release, please contact me so that I can arrange to inspect the documents or decide which documents I wish to have copied. Please also provide an invoice and a cost breakdown of the fee estimate. If the fees are less than $25.00, please copy and send the records and invoice as soon as possible, and we will promptly pay the required costs.

Thank you for your consideration of this request. If you have any questions or concerns, or if I can provide any clarification that will help identify responsive documents or focus this request, please do not hesitate to contact me at ALPR@eff.org. 
                                          	 
Sincerely,
 
Jennifer Pinsof
Staff Attorney 
Electronic Frontier Foundation

communications.subject: Your Oakland, CA public records request #24-1170 has been opened.
communications.communication:
Oakland, CA ************************************************************************ Your record request #24-1170 has been submitted successfully. Thank you for submitting a request for public records through the City of Oakland's NextRequest system. Your request will be delivered to the appropriate City Departments or Officials. The City of Oakland is committed to transparency and to providing you with a full and timely response to your request. If we need to clarify your request in order to provide a complete response, we will contact you directly or post a reply in NextRequest. communications.subject: Your Oakland, CA public records request #24-1170 has been closed.
communications.communication:
Oakland, CA ************************************************************************ Record request #24-1170 has been closed. The closure reason supplied was: OPD did not have any ALPR equipment active during 2023 and began utilizing Flock ALPR cameras in July 2024.    ·                     The attachment labeled 24-1170_Attachment1(A1A3) has the records that are responsive to part A1 and A3.  ·                     The attachment labeled 24-1170_Attachment2(A2A4) has the records that are responsive to part A2 and A4.  ·                     OPD has a 30-day retention period with Flock. In response to parts B3 and B4, as of 7:08 a.m. PDT on March 10th, 2024, there were 1,594,204 vehicles detected in the last 30 days and 70,552 hotlist hits in the last 30 days. *Please see attached documents for remaining response to your request. ************************************************************************ Questions about your request? Reply to this email or sign in to contact staff at Oakland, CA.

title: Department of Education Letters to 60 Universities and Colleges (Santa Monica College)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Department of Education Letters to 60 Universities and Colleges (Santa Monica College)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of the letter sent to your institution by the United States Department of Education on or about March 10, 2025, referencing Title VI. The letter is referenced in this press release: https://www.ed.gov/about/news/press-release/us-department-of-educations-office-civil-rights-sends-letters-60-universities-under-investigation-antisemitic-discrimination-and-harassment.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

title: Licensed officers and total employees

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Licensed officers and total employees
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all organized datasets containing the most recent information about the number of licensed officers and total employees per agency for every Virginia law enforcement agency,  in a machine-readable database or spreadsheet format such as Excel, CSV, Access, SQL or JSON. 

The data should include all fields in the database or spreadsheets that contain non-exempt information. I also request all documentation that describes the layout of the database’s tables and fields, and that provides the definitions of any field names, codes, and abbreviations used in the database. This information may be gathered together in a single document like a data dictionary, entity layout, or user's guide. If that is the case, I request access to and copy of said document.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with Dillon Bergin.

communications.subject: FOIA Request - Licensed Officers and Total Employees
communications.communication:
Tom Nash,

This office is in receipt of your request for records made in accordance with the Virginia Freedom of Information Act (§2.2-3700 et seq.), which we received 1/29/2025. Please be advised that it is not possible to provide the requested records within the five working days required by FOIA because of the review process required for this request. Therefore, we are invoking subsection B 4 of §2.2-3704 to provide us with seven additional working days to respond to your request. The deadline to respond will be Friday, February 14, 2025.

Thank you,
Payne Tarkenton

FOIA Officer

Virginia Department of Criminal Justice Services

1100 Bank Street, Richmond, VA 23219

Phone 804-786-3051

communications.subject: FOIA Request - Certified Officers
communications.communication:
Tom Nash,



This email is meant to serve as a response to your request for records made in accordance with the Virginia Freedom of Information Act (Virginia Code § 2.2-3700 et seq.), in which you requested datasets containing the most recent information about the number of licensed officers and total employees per agency for every Virginia law enforcement agency. DCJS received a deposit for an outstanding previous FOIA request from you and/or your organization on March 3, 2025, and processed this request beginning on that date.



Attached to this email, you will find an Excel spreadsheet that contains the number of certified officers and/or jailers at each law enforcement agency in the Commonwealth. However, please be aware that contrary to the language used in your FOIA request, Virginia does not license officers; Virginia only certifies officers. In addition, DCJS does not have information on the total employees of each Virginia law enforcement agency, only the certified law enforcement officers reported to DCJS by the individual agencies.  Accordingly, pursuant to Va. Code § 2.2-3704.B(3) DCJS responds that no such records exist regarding the total employees of each Virginia law enforcement agency.


As you requested, this information has been provided "in a machine-readable database or spreadsheet format such as Excel..."



Thank you,

Payne Tarkenton

FOIA Officer

Virginia Department of Criminal Justice Services

1100 Bank Street, Richmond, VA 23219

Phone 804-786-3051

www.dcjs.virginia.gov<http://www.dcjs.virginia.gov/>



For up to date information, subscribe to "DCJS Updates": www.dcjs.virginia.gov/subscribe<http://www.dcjs.virginia.gov/subscribe>

Tom Nash,

This email is meant to serve as a response to your request for records made in accordance with the Virginia Freedom of Information Act (Virginia Code § 2.2-3700 et seq.), in which you requested the database of criminal justice agencies that sends data to the Criminal Justice Agency Directory lookup. DCJS received a deposit for an outstanding previous FOIA request from you and/or your organization on March 3, 2025, and processed this request beginning on that date.

Attached to this email, you will find an Excel spreadsheet that contains the agency name, website URL, and contact information for the point of contact as submitted by each agency in the Criminal Justice Agency Directory lookup. As you requested, this information has been provided "in a machine-readable database or spreadsheet format such as Excel..."

Thank you,
Payne Tarkenton

FOIA Officer

Virginia Department of Criminal Justice Services

1100 Bank Street, Richmond, VA 23219

Phone 804-786-3051

www.dcjs.virginia.gov<http://www.dcjs.virginia.gov/>



For up to date information, subscribe to "DCJS Updates": www.dcjs.virginia.gov/subscribe<http://www.dcjs.virginia.gov/subscribe>
Visit us on Facebook: www.facebook.com/vadcjs<http://www.facebook.com/vadcjs> and Flickr: www.flickr.com/photos/va_dcjs<http://www.flickr.com/photos/va_dcjs>

CONFIDENTIALITY NOTICE:
The contents of this email message and any attachments are intended solely for the addressee(s) and may contain confidential and/or privileged information and may be legally protected from disclosure. If you are not the intended recipient of this message or their agent, or if this message has been addressed to you in error, please immediately alert the sender by reply email and then delete this message and any attachments. If you are not the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any use, dissemination, copying, or storage of this message or its attachments is strictly prohibited.

title: Middle Tenn FRS

communications.subject: Tennessee Public Records Act Request: Middle Tenn FRS
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Tennessee Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

To Whom It May Concern,

I request the NCAA Membership Financial Reporting System revenue and expense reports for fiscal (or reporting) years 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020 & 2024.  Specifically:  

These reports are completed by the athletic department for the National Collegiate Athletic Association for the fiscal years listed above. This report is a multi-page document that had to be submitted to the NCAA in January. It contains 40+ revenue and expense categories, followed by specific breakdowns of each of those categories, by sport and gender. I am requesting the full report, including the detail tables, the “Other Reporting Items” list and the “Statement of Revenues and Expenses” that appears at the end of the report. PLEASE NOTE: The NCAA report is different than the equity report that is sent to the U.S. Department of Education for Title IX compliance.

I prefer to receive the records electronically as an Adobe Acrobat (.pdf) file.

If you choose to deny this request, please provide a written explanation for the denial including a reference to the specific statutory exemption(s) on which you rely.  Also, please provide all segregable portions of otherwise exempt material.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kent Hoover, a citizen of Tennessee, in coordination with Stacey Brook.

title: FOIA Navy record Timothy Prusak, USN ret

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FOIA Navy record Timothy Prusak, USN ret
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

The Official Military Personnel File (OMPF) for Timothy Paul Prusak (born January 18, 1950)  including all Fitness Report and Counseling forms NAVPERS Form 1610/2, Enlisted performance evaluation reports NAVPERS Form 1616-1, history of assignments NAVPERS form 601-5 and/or NAVPERS form 1070/605, the Background Summary (NAVPERS Form 1640/32), Navy Training History NAVPERS form 601-4, Most recent Cumulative Record of Training (NAVPERS Form 5300/16), all military awards and full citations, military education/training courses 
and Form DD-214. 
Also request Bronze Star Medal and Navy Commendation medal full Citations. Mr Prusak was a decorated veteran of the Vietnam War, buried at Arlington National Cemetery, final resting place of our nations heroes. https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/49301753/timothy-p-prusak
If necessary please redact any sensitive information protected in accordance with the Privacy Act of 1974.

VETERAN INFORMATION
Name of veteran: Timothy Paul Prusak
Branch of service: United States Navy
Rank: Chief Warrant Officer 
Dates of military service: Approximately 1968 - 1995
Date of birth: January 18, 1950
Date of death: November 3, 2002 

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest. News of passing reported public domain.  The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Donavan Turner

Sincerely,

Jen Dean

title: Cadet Chapel at West Point

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Cadet Chapel at West Point
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Related to The Cadet Chapel at West Point, pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) for the past 10 years.

As there have been court cases where the government has been required to release records under FOIA, I trust that you will comply with my request. For example, in American Civil Liberties Union v. Central Intelligence Agency (2019), the court ruled that the government could not withhold or redact records related to the CIA's use of drone strikes. Additionally, in Competitive Enterprise Institute v. Office of Science and Technology Policy (2020), the court ruled that the government must release certain records related to climate change policy.

I am requesting access to the following records:

Architectural drawings and blueprints of The Cadet Chapel, including any revisions or updates made over the past 10 years.
Records related to the construction and maintenance of The Cadet Chapel over the past 10 years, including any contracts or agreements with contractors and vendors.
Records related to the funding of The Cadet Chapel over the past 10 years, including any budget reports or financial statements.
Any records related to events or ceremonies held at The Cadet Chapel over the past 10 years, including guest lists, program materials, and photographs.
To facilitate your search for the requested documents, please let me know if there are any specific offices or departments that may hold the requested documents.

I am requesting that you do not redact, withhold, or delete any responsive records. If any documents are withheld or redacted, I will seek a court order to compel their release. Please note that the government's obligation to disclose records under FOIA is a cornerstone of transparency and accountability, and I urge you to fully comply with my request.

Finally, I would like to make a special request for any records related to the history and significance of The Cadet Chapel at West Point. As a landmark building with a rich history, I am interested in learning more about the cultural and historical significance of The Cadet Chapel, and any information you can provide would be greatly appreciated.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: Cadet Chapel at West Point
communications.communication:
Dear Danielle R. Tymoczko,

Thank you for your response regarding my FOIA request for records related to The Cadet Chapel at West Point. I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter.

Regarding your request for the contract number related to the construction and maintenance of The Cadet Chapel over the past 10 years, I apologize for any confusion. I do not have a specific contract number as I am not aware of any specific contracts or agreements related to the construction and maintenance of the chapel during that time period. However, I am requesting access to any and all records related to such contracts or agreements that may exist within the specified timeframe.

In addition to my original request, I would also like to request access to any pamphlets, videos, audio recordings, or historical documents related to The Cadet Chapel at West Point. Specifically, I am interested in any documents or recordings that provide information about the history, significance, or cultural importance of the chapel. This would include, but is not limited to, any historical documents related to the building, any pamphlets or brochures distributed about the chapel, and any videos or audio recordings related to events or ceremonies held at the chapel.

Thank you again for your assistance with this request. Please let me know if you require any additional information or clarification.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

Specifically, I am interested in any documents or recordings that provide information about the history, significance, or cultural importance of the chapel. This would include, but is not limited to, any historical documents related to the building, any pamphlets or brochures distributed about the chapel, and any videos or audio recordings related to events or ceremonies held at the chapel.”


In an effort to fulfill your request and avoid confusion, may you please submit the additional information cited above in to one request. Once received, your request will be placed in que for processing. Furthermore, you will receive an acknowledgement letter with a tracking number.




Should you have any further questions or concerns, please feel free to contact me.

communications.subject: FOIA #FP-23-019125
communications.communication:
Good Morning,

We hope this email finds you well. Our office is reaching out to you regarding your FOIA request. The request asks for “Records related to the construction and maintenance of The Cadet Chapel over the past 10 years, including any contracts or agreements with contractors and vendors.” Without stating contract numbers, names of vendors, and specific known agreements, this portion of the request would not be fulfilled. May you please narrow the scope of your request as some proponents are too broad. We appreciate your understanding and patience with this matter.


Should you have any further questions or concerns, please feel free to contact me.

Thank you and have a nice day!

Respectfully,

The West Point FOIA Office

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #FP-23-019125
communications.communication:
Thank you for reaching out and for the update on my FOIA request regarding records related to the construction and maintenance of The Cadet Chapel over the past 10 years.

To help facilitate the processing of my request, I would like to narrow the scope as follows:

	1.	Timeframe: Please limit the search to records from the past 5 years instead of 10.
	2.	Contracts and Agreements: Focus on contracts or agreements specifically related to major renovations, repairs, or structural maintenance of The Cadet Chapel.
	3.	Vendors: If possible, please include records related to contracts with the primary contractors responsible for significant work on the Chapel, such as architectural firms, construction companies, or restoration specialists.

If additional details or clarifications are needed, please let me know, and I will be happy to assist further. I appreciate your continued assistance and look forward to your response.

Thank you and have a great day!

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter
